thread.title: K-State embarrassed at home in 55-0 loss to Oklahoma
thread.title_full: K-State embarrassed at home in 55-0 loss to Oklahoma - KCTV5

author: Posted by Chris Oberholtz, Multimedia Producer
title: K-State embarrassed at home in 55-0 loss to Oklahoma
text:
MANHATTAN, KS (FOOTBALLKC) - Coming off of two straight heartbreaking losses to top ranked teams, Kansas State took a step back Saturday as No.19 Oklahoma rolled easily to a victory in Manhattan.
The blowout loss is the biggest home shutout in school history, and one of the worst Bill Snyder can remember.
"All of us are embarrassed," Snyder said. "I can’t remember being involved in a game like this since 1989, the first year that we were here, and I don’t even know that we had one this bad."
For how well Kansas State played in Oklahoma State and at home against TCU, they played equally as bad against the Sooners on both sides of the ball.
Offensively, John Hubener paled in comparison to his counterpart Baker Mayfield, as Hubener was just four for 14 with 39 yards and two interceptions. Mayfield was on a whole new level, tossing five touchdowns and racking up 282 yards.
Hubener received little help in the run game, as Kody Cook only rushed for 19 yards and Charles Cook 18 yards. The Wildcats were only able to account for 110-yards on the day.
The defensive unit didn’t have much time to rest in between possessions, but never did have an answer for the Sooner attack. Mixon, Perine, and Brooks all took over 10 carries for at least 41 yards, with Mixon taking one of his 15 carries into the end zone.
The Sooners were extremely effective in reading the defense and setting up each facet of the game, as running screens on blitz’s and going deep when K-State packed the box, provided lots of offensive fireworks early.
Cook did come in at the end of the game in place of Hubener, but did little to impress going one for eight and throwing an interception.
After two strong performances against top teams, the blowout loss might have been inevitable for the heavily injured Wildcat squad. Dropping to 3-3 on the season, Kansas State is in need of win to snap their three game losing streak.
They’ll look to pull it off with an easier matchup on Saturday, as the Wildcats travel to Texas to take on the Longhorns at 11:00 a.m.
